channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-12564] consolidate the getTableDescriptors() semantic
item.description:
Master getTableDescriptors() which is called by Admin.listTables() has a couple of different behaviors depending on how it is called.

after HBASE-12073 with the AccessController enabled, we now get a "global admin" required if listTables() is called without a regex otherwise we return only the table that the user can see (we show only the tables that the user have access to, which means or the user is a global admin or it has a table-level create/admin). We probably should have the second behavior even without regex, since I should able to see "my own tables".

getTableDescriptors() is returning only non system tables. Tools like user_permission that are doing "for each listTable(): userPerm(table)" are losing the system tables, so stuff like user_permission 'hbase:acls' will not result any result.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
v0 removes the deprecated Connection.listTables() added with HBASE-12073 (which is only in master) in favor of the Admin API (as suggested by the doc).
v0 changes the getTableDescriptors() right check for the "list all" returning only the tables that the user can see (table level Admin/Create).
v0 adds a new option to listTables() allowing to return the sys-tables, which is useful to user_permission.

I was thinking to add the same AccessController logic of getTableDescriptors() to getTableNames(), which at the moment returns all the table names without asking anything (see HBASE-9182). I think the behavior should be "give me all the names that I have access to" so the AccessController should filter the tables like getTableDescriptors() but checking also Read/Write rights and not only Admin/Create. Andrew Purtell?

This message is automatically generated.

The patch looks good to me. Some minor concerns.

  • IMO using if(req.getIncludeSysTables() || desc.getTableName().isSystemTable()) would be more readable. 
    
 if(!(!req.getIncludeSysTables() && desc.getTableName().isSystemTable())) {
  • Replace hbase:acl using constants ? 
    
+    // Verify that we can read sys-tables

+    assertEquals(1, SUPERUSER.runAs(getPrivilegedAction("hbase:acl")).size());
  • How about one more assert statement with null value for regex so that HBASE-12301 will get validated too?

•IMO using if(req.getIncludeSysTables() || desc.getTableName().isSystemTable()) would be more readable.

In this case if table is sytem table and user set includeSysTables to false then may end up adding it into descriptors. Which is not correct right ?
May be you wanted to suggest 

if(req.getIncludeSysTables() && desc.getTableName().isSystemTable())

when both are true then only add this system table in the descriptors list.

Ashish Singh none of the above is correct, Srikanth Srungarapu forgot a not on the isSystemTable() which was the version in his patch.

if (req.getIncludeSysTables() || !desc.getTableName().isSystemTable()) add the desc

if you want to include the sys-tables, every descriptor is valid so you add everything, otherwise you just add the non sys-tables

v1 adds the ACLs checks to listTableNames().
basically you can only see the tables you have access to.
so getTableDescriptors() and listTableNames() have the same behavior.

We also have two similar methods ListNamespaceDescriptors() and ListTableDescriptorsByNamespace() that now are doing the same thing as getTableDescriptor() and listTableNames() with a filter on the ns but they don't have any ACL check. I'll open a new jira to remove them (or at least aligning them to the getTableDescriptor() and listTableNames())

This message is automatically generated.

I think the behavior should be "give me all the names that I have access to" so the AccessController should filter the tables like getTableDescriptors() but checking also Read/Write rights and not only Admin/Create. Andrew Purtell?

No, users with read or write access should not be granted permission to potentially sensitive information in the schema.

Anyway I looked at the v2 patch and it seems to do the right thing, we won't return descriptors unless the user has ADMIN or CREATE permissions in dominant scope. In postGetTableNames we will return table names if the user has any of the Action bits in dominant scope, but that doesn't seem to be a problem, it follows that a user with any access to a table must know its name to make use of it.

No, users with read or write access should not be granted permission to potentially sensitive information in the schema.

yeah, sorry maybe I was not clear. I was talking about the getTableNames() which just returns the table names. In that case if the user have "access" to the table (by access I mean any RWXCA on any level of the table) the shell "list" will display the names (only names).
while for the descriptor as you said only users granted with ADMIN/CREATE can see the table schema.

+1 for master branch only.

We need the String and Pattern permutations? (Especially when Pattern gets turned into a String down in pb util for shipping to master)

For future no need to repeat javadoc if an @Override – javadoc tool picks up the Interace javadoc for you.

Nice cleanup Matteo Bertozzi
